item.title: Jess Butler
item.description: Superb journalism in El Pa√≠s todayManuel Ansede looked at the publications of Spain's top academics and found scams upon scamsHe didn't find a few bad apples, but institutionalised cheating for metrics"Spanish universities have become veritable ‚Äúfactory farms‚Äù for insubstantial studies...data shows that, in 2015, barely 0.9% of Spanish production was published in MDPI journals...Six years later, the percentage in Spain shot up to nearly 15%"https://english.elpais.com/science-tech/2023-06-04/a-researcher-who-publishes-a-study-every-two-days-reveals-the-darker-side-of-science.html

item.title: ChrisO_wiki
item.description:
1/ This very good thread on Twitter from Tom Giuretis highlights the vital role that the canals fed from the Dnipro play in the agriculture of southern Ukraine and Crimea. But I thought I'd add a historical perspective to how the canals changed life there.
https://twitter.com/TomGiuretis/status/1666062460967690240

item.title: Maggie
item.description: @schoppik @Meryem_Fuat This definitely just made me laugh imagining some nonsense political solution. Like why are you guys worried, this is just RETRO! We'll just bump some Donna Summers and everything will be fine

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description: What is Kuru?A big accomplishments list of NINDS (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke) has several references to a disorder I had never heard of, Kuru. What is it? It was a disorder in the 1950s/60s that launched our understanding of prion diseases. Prion diseases are those bizarre diseases that consistent solely of the exposure to misfolded proteins that cause other proteins to misfold as well (they are not viruses).https://www.ninds.nih.gov/health-information/disorders/kuru

item.title: Steve Haroz (@sharoz on üê§)
item.description: @BorisBarbour @adam42smith Potential limitations of the NSF's new open data policy:1. No auditing beyond researcher self-reporting. How would NSF know if someone isn't compliant?2. No reporting mechanism. If you can't get data from an NSF-funded paper, there's no one to complain to.3. No mandatory justification of excuses for not sharing.4. No explicit prohibition of "available on request". If it's in a university repo with a password that only the authors know, is that compliant?

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
Short-term synaptic plasticity in working memory. Why not? Muscles get bigger when you use them.Mechanical transmission at spine synapses: Short-term potentiation and working memory

item.description: Get your shingles vaccine, it can also reduce your risk of dementia.https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-01824-1

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: That 2020 #Nature article essentially promising a cure for Parkinson's (substantia nigral astrocytes reprogrammed to neurones which then innervate the striatum)? Another failed replication:https://pubpeer.com/publications/E9B9EE62FECAE39782EB27EA238930#21But you heard it first via PubPeer, where this analysis was posted within a month of publication. Install the PubPeer extensions to get early warnings.

item.title: (((Jann Gobble)))üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà
item.description: To those reviewers of #VisionPro complaining "Why would a father hide himself behind a set of goggles at his kid's birthday party? They should spend that time w/their kids, not with their face hidden."I say: You must be young...you don't remember your parent hiding behind a behemoth of a VHS camera the size of a small suitcase.They're too used to holding an #iPhone at shoulder height - face in full view.Some of us remember. And we lived through it as kids. We're fine. Unscarred.#WWDC

item.title: Maggie McFee
Emeritus Prof Christopher May
item.description: Last week I posted Rowan Atkinson's piece in which he cast doubt on the current viability fo #electriccars & some of you replied with opposing analyses suggesting EVs can & should be more widely used & are already helping battle the #clinatecrisis Now the Guardian itself has put up an extensive debunking of Atkinson's anti- #electricvehicles arguments, which I am also happy to post - not least as much will be familiar to you from last weeks' comments in the timelinehttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jun/08/fact-check-why-rowan-atkinson-is-wrong-about-electric-vehicles

item.title: Gregg Gonsalves
item.description: This is outrageous. Spread the word. Are you a US researcher working w foreign institutions? There is something awful brewing: "For foreign subrecipients, the subrecipient to provide copies of all lab notebooks, all data, all documentation that supports the research outcomes as described in the progress report. These supporting materials must be provided to prime recipient with each scientific update (no less than once every six months, or more frequently based on risks). https://rfi.grants.nih.gov/?s=646e6654a8ba09024f09e852

item.title: Thiago Carvalho
item.description:
My Clinical Pipeline column for Nature Medicine this week examines the state of Sarepta's new gene therapy for Duchenne muscular dystrophy application at the FDA. Whatever its final efficacy turns out to be, the general strategy behind the therapy, an engineered micro-dystrophin is very clever. It was inspired by the case of a 61 year old patient who had a deletion of almost half of his dystrophin gene and was still alive and walking. Here's that ref, from 1990:
https://www.nature.com/articles/343180a0And here's my column:https://www.nature.com/articles/d41591-023-00052-4

item.title: Martin Owens
item.description: Have we thought about naming these wildfires after the current CEOs and large investors of fossil fuel companies?You know, so we know who to blame.Bit like we do for hurricanes. But with first and last names.#ClimeCrisis #ClimateChange #wildfires

item.title: Jo Jitsu
item.description: Best understandable plans I've seen so far to build a corsi-rosenthal box. Everything else I've seen was practically gibberish.#airquality #airpurifier #diy #wildfires #covid
